title: RP adjustment in Oceania
body:
Greetings summoners, I’m Mirko (MasterMirkinen) and I head up Riot Oceania.  

I just want to take a moment to talk to you about RP Prices. In an effort to ensure price equality on the server and respond to rising costs caused by recent economic shifts, we are adjusting the cost of RP in Oceania. This will result in a 13% RP price increase for Australian players.

This change will take effect in two weeks on March 20th at 11:59PM Sydney Time. We are delaying the actual change in prices to give players one last chance to stock up before the change. 

Here are the new amounts of RP you will receive as of 21/03/2015 for credit cards

**For Credit Card**
BASE+BONUS=TOTAL
5 AUD/NZD - 520+0=520
10 AUD/NZD - 1040+60=1100
20 AUD/NZD - 80+170=2250
35 AUD/NZD - 3640+360=4000
50 AUD/NZD - 5200+700=5900
100 AUD/NZD - 10400+1700=12100

**For Prepaid Card**
BASE + BONUS RP = TOTAL
10 AUD/NZD - 1100+0=1100
25 AUD/NZD - 2750+80=2830
50 AUD/NZD - 5500+400=5900

We want to be transparent in doing this and have provided some more context below:

**Why are we increasing prices?**
This will be our first price increase in almost two years, so why now? It really boils down to server fairness and rising cost due to economic shifts. 

We attempt to keep RP prices in relative balance, especially when on the same server. Back in October, the Australian dollar started weakening against the New Zealand dollar and it caught us by surprise. This depreciation has resulted in pricing discrepancies between the Oceanic countries. We monitored the situation for several months hoping that it would recover, but we are now at a point where a price change is necessary.

Unfortunately, simply reducing New Zealand prices alone won’t fix this. Another factor we need to take into consideration is the exchange rate between local currencies and USD. Because a big part of our costs come from the US, where the dollar continues to rise, we need to consider prices relative to the US as well. Therefore, we have decided to raise prices in Australia to bring them back into balance with New Zealand and the US.

**Are there any other reasons a price change can happen?**
There are many factors that determine how we price globally. In this case, server fairness and costs due to currency were the primary drivers. However, we also monitor other factors such as inflation or substantial infrastructure investment. So far we haven’t felt the need to make changes for these reasons. 

**What about other regions?**
When economic environments change to a point where it places regions out of balance, then we look to make adjustments. Recently, we’ve made adjustments to RP prices in Brazil, Turkey, Russia, Chile and Argentina, and today we are introducing changes to regions including Oceania, Europe and Canada. 

**Any impact on IP or existing content?**
Nope. You can still purchase content for the same amount of IP and RP as before. 

**Does the change affect already bought prepaid cards?**
It will affect the card from the changeover date, which is one of the reasons we’re giving players 2 weeks notice to redeem cards while the value of RP is unchanged.

If you have any questions about this process please post them in the comments below!

Posting here most frequent questions from you and the answers:

**Does it mean that every time the dollar goes up or down we will have a change in the RP prices?**
> No. There are many things that factor into pricing decisions besides just currency - such as interest rates, inflation, competition, costs, investment into League of Legends and parity across countries.
At the same time, we don't want to create an artificial stock market for RP. It is not our intention to constantly change prices with relative movements in currencies and create a lot of speculation among players. 
Therefore we have decided to monitor the situation and to make changes only if currencies or inflation make significant long term moves.
We don't take this decisions very lightly as evidence by the fact that we waited several months before making these chances here.
 
**Why didn't you change the prices when the Australian dollar was stronger than the US dollar?**
>Changing RP prices is not something we want to do every time there is a currency variation. We decided to make changes only if currencies or inflation make **significant long term moves**.
If you look at [this graph](http://apollo-uploads-oce.s3.amazonaws.com/1425611690499/6-3-152-08-21PM.png), you can see the exchange rate of AUD and USD since we launched here in Oceania. When we launched, we positioned our prices slightly lower than the US because we were not sure where the dollar was going.
Any time the currency went above that line, in OCE we paid a bit more. As you can see, it happened only once and for a short time.

**Why is the US dollar even a factor for OCE prices?**
>While we have a passionate local team here in SYD, it's important to remember that many of our costs are in US Dollars, which are currently trending strongly against most global currencies. Some of these increased costs will be offset by the price increases.
Each region (OCE in this case) should be responsible for covering its own costs to publish the game (servers, community, etc), but all regions should contribute to the costs of developing the game (programmers, artists, etc).

**As a purchaser of RP, it would be reassuring to know that Riot is investing in OCE though (infrastructure, community, eSport...)**
> While community and eSport is probably easier to see, we are doing a poor job in sharing what we are doing in OCE on the infrustructure and connectivity front.
We have done TONS of things to improve connection and even more are in the pipeline but we simply didn't inform you. Please have a look at this post from Agent Mindstar with some more information: http://boards.oce.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/announcements/MXv9uHnL-rp-adjustment-in-oceania?comment=0014000000000001

**Why don't you simply charge OCE players in USD?**
>We actually thought about that when we launched but we believed that having prices in local currency would be more transparent for our players.
Also, some more younger players, may not understand the difference with the international currency and think that they are paying a certain amount in AUD while they are paying that amount in USD (which would be a higher AUD)
Basically we believe that having prices in USD would make our players unsure of the real cost they are paying.
With today exchange rate for example you would see something like this:

>5 USD	650
10 USD	1380
20 USD	2800
35 USD 	5000
50 USD	7200
100 USD	15000

>with in your bank statement would appear like this:

>6.423845 AUD
12.84769 AUD
25.69538 AUD
44.966915 AUD
64.23845 AUD
128.4769 AUD

>We believe this is more confusing that keeping prices in local currency (which BTW, if you check today's exchange rate, OCE prices are still cheaper than the US$)
BTW, even with today's increase, the prices in OCE are lower than in N.A.

Hey M3RV & Zeja

These are some great questions, and I think it highlights an area where we could be communicating a bit better (something we are trying to work on).  One reason we aren't quite so transparent on the specifics of our network & server infrastructure is that we prefer to keep the architecture and some details of the configuration private.  This is because if too much information is out there, it becomes much easier understand & attack potential weak spots, which wouldn't be fun for anyone.

That said, we actually do invest quite a lot of effort into infrastructure specifically for the Oceanic server and I'd like to give a quick rundown of some of the key achievements we've made over the last year.

**Internet Connectivity**

When we opened the Oceanic server, we had a single internet connection in place for our game servers.  This worked but players were dependent on how good their ISPs connection to our ISP was for their connection to League.  That can be quite variable at time, and often introduces issues that are completely outside a players', or Riot's, control.

Over the last year we have added direct connections to a number of the most popular ISPs, providing a much better connection path for players on those ISPs to reach us.  We have some big goals to improve this further over the next 12 months, and this is a big area of focus for the team here.

Example: TPG & Firewall errors.
We added a direct peering link with TPG in September.  Beforehand, a very large number of TPG players (including some local Rioters) experienced the firewall error very regularly.  This was due to TPG players having poor connectivity to League through the ISPs Riot were using at the time.  We added a direct link between TPG's network and Riots network, which was able to bypass the problem connections, and the result was a much more stable experience for TPG players.

**Infrastructure Improvements**

Globally, Riot learns a lot from the services we run, and a cycle of improvements based on this is usually ongoing.  Oceania is not excepted from this learning and improvement.  A huge part of the job we do locally is to make sure we adopt changes that matter for our region.

As an example, during the second half of last year, the Oceanic servers underwent a complete architecture refresh for our game server networking.  This was aimed at adopting the latest service architecture updates - future-proofing the service, and beefing up network security.

**Infrastructure Costs**

The Oceanic league server is actually a mix of non-latency dependent infrastructure in the USA, and latency sensitive infrastructure in Australia.  Infrastructure costs in Australia are actually quite high compared to the rest of the world (server internet bandwidth, for example, costs 5x - 10x more).  By putting portions of our infrastructure in North America, we actually reduce a lot of potential cost, however there is some sensitivity to Australian Dollar fluctuations as a result.

This is of course in addition to the very separate development costs (mentioned in the original post) associated with new league features and functionality.

**Summary**

Going forward, I think we can do a better job of communicating some of this information to players, and will definitely look to do so where appropriate.  I hope this has done a little to explain some of the behind-the-scenes stuff we do for the tech side of things here in Oceania.

Cheers and thanks for reading.

Hmmm I'm not particularly keen on this logic. The RP system is inherently deceptive in itself - publishers have long been using this model to veil the true cost of a transaction (spending 1350 RP or 'X' Microsoft points or gold coins or whatever dissociates a consumer from the true cost of the thing they're buying). It's an established model whereby publishers actively try and discourage consumers from doing the maths - Riot certainly isn't the first or the only ones to employ it but this particular reason why it's used isn't in doubt. I'm not having a go at you, Mirko, but I don't think it's fair to say that providing *extra* information about the USD value of an RP bundle is going to be confusing for customers. On a slight tangent, by requiring RP to be bought in non-refundable bundles (as opposed to being able to buy something in a discrete transaction), Riot gains the benefit of holding/investing the dollar value amount of unspent RP - that adds up to an astronomical amount of even simple interest over the full volume of RP transactions - far more than traditional businesses because there's no warehouse holding skins/content waiting to ship and almost no cost in 'shipping' them. The RP model certainly isn't consumer friendly and any information that would make it more consumer friendly would be greatly appreciated from our point of view I think.

This is a reply to a comment I saw posted elsewhere but I don't want to seem like I'm angrily replying to multiple comments, so I'll reply here as well :) Granted it's been a while since I've looked at the Australian accounting standards, but I believe it's creative accounting that says that OCE should house a percentage of US R&D costs. As a regional (largely retail) expansion of an already established business model, the OCE budget shouldn't be wearing development costs that are occurring in another jurisdiction. To the extent that OCE expends funds on localising these assets, fair enough, but otherwise, no. If the argument was that OCE's costs have gone up due to the rolling out of the OPL or local programs such as the Ocean Week stuff, then I can get behind it. I think, as you said elsewhere, a large part of the problem is that it's hard to see what Riot OCE is doing for OCE players separate from the stuff that every region gets. Communication of this would go a long way to making people happier I think.

Having said all of the above, this isn't anything new - Australians have been paying more for video games since forever and also I understand that costs go up over time. However, as the explanation has been couched in economic terms and specifically, exchange rate differentials, it's also worth noting that this adjustment has come at a *really* bad time for Australian consumers. The AUD is at a historically weak point against the USD (the last time it was this low was for a six month period back in 08/09). Interest rates can't get much lower than they are now and when they start to go back up, the AUD will start to appreciate again. The big thing for me, is: can we get some sort of indication that if the AUD gains against the USD, we can expect another adjustment of RP prices? Or rather, because Maraudaur stated that you guys don't want to constantly adjust prices, at what magnitude of change in the exchange rate can we expect an adjustment?

I'm going to give you a comparison, to demonstrate how what you wrote is actually the opposite. 
Lets imagine part of the OCE server malfunction, and a part need to placed.
Riot OCE contact the distributor in USA (seeing as everything needs to be the same as the NA server set up), and purchases an $100 USD replacement. 
-  If the AUD dollar was about 1:1 with the USD as it was when OCE opened up, they would pay $100 AUD.
-  If the AUD was at current rates 1:0.76 USD then OCE would need to pay $130 AUD for the same piece of equipment. 

Hence they pay more not less when the dollar decreases in value.

Operating costs in AUD are only a part of the overall operating cost for the OCE server.  Australia is actually one of the more expensive places in the world to build out presence (cost of hardware + bandwidth is significantly higher).  For this reason, we actually host a lot of the OCE infrastructure in the USA, with only latency sensitive parts residing locally.

This gives us the benefit of being able to provide players with low ping to our game servers, without the expensive cost we would incur if the entire platform infrastructure was local.  Even for hardware purchased locally, the currency risk you mention is often built in at a supplier level - ie. they take into account the cost of purchasing a piece of equipment overseas and delivering it to the AU market. 

That means that a reasonable portion of our operational costs for our platform actually are in USD.  Even though they are much lower than if they were in AUD, we are impacted by shifts in relative currency value.

A business exists to make money. While some businesses raise prices immorally, leaving customers feeling extorted, this is not the case here. Rito have reasonably explained why the price is being raised: to compensate for the falling Aussie dollar and maintain global pricing consistency. 

I'm not sure why the community interpret this as a reason to ask for more investment in the game, since revenue concerns have obviously pushed the OCE division of the company to alter the price of their biggest moneymaking product.

If this decision was made without the current economic background, I would be all for pushing for new features, game modes etc. There's a lot of great analysis here from the community, but I'm yet to see a single post that looks at the bigger picture (although an honourable mention does go to FruitSalad - good job mate).

When it comes down to it, the OCE division do a great job with limited resources and they've demonstrated an ongoing commitment to their players. If they need to ask a bit more from the community and they do so reasonably and ethically then so be it. It's obviously a decision that hasn't been made lightly and has been handled very well here by the admins.

Keep up the good work
